bestBHT.bht: A good pastor must have two concerns: teaching earnestly and remaining pure. His teaching alone is not sufficient; his conduct must align with the doctrine he preaches. By holding fast to both his personal holiness and his teaching, he will save both himself and those who listen to him. It is crucial for a pastor to pay close attention to himself, ensuring that his life and teaching align with right principles. By doing so, he not only preserves himself from worldly corruption, but also becomes instrumental in the eternal salvation of others.

Henry Alford: A good pastor ought to have two cares—to be earnest, in teaching, and to keep himself pure.
Nor will his doctrine avail much unless his honesty and sanctity of life be correspondent thereto.
Thou shalt save both thyself, and those that hear thee, in the power of thine influence over them, by God's word and ordinances.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 'His teaching will be of no avail unless his own life accord with it; and his own purity of life is not enough unless he be diligent in teaching.'
Albert Barnes: There is no religion in a filthy person; in uncouth manners; in an inconvenient and strange form of apparel; in bad grammar, and in slovenly habits - and to be a real gentleman should be as much a matter of conscience with a minister of the gospel as to be a real Christian.

He was to 'take heed' to the whole business of public instruction; that is, both to the matter and the manner. The great object was to get as much truth as possible before the minds of his hearers, and in such a way as to produce the deepest impression on them.
A faithful minister will be the means of saving many sinners. This assurance furnishes a ground of encouragement for a minister of the gospel. He may hope for success, and should look for success.
Marvin Vincent: Take heed. Quite frequent in LXX Lit. hold upon, fasten thy attention on.
In Philippians 2:16, to hold out or present, a sense which is found only in Class.
John Calvin: There are two things of which a good pastor should be careful; to be diligent in teaching, and to keep himself pure.

It is no ordinary spur to excite the thoughtfulness of pastors when they learn that their own salvation, as well as that of the people, depends on the industry and perseverance with which they devote themselves to their office.
If thus a good pastor is the salvation of his hearers, let bad and careless men know that their destruction must be ascribed to those who have the charge of them.
Philip Schaff: Take heed to thyself and to the doctrine."
Archibald T. Robertson: Keep on paying attention to thyself."
And to the teaching. This is important also.
Stick to the business of framing your own life and your teaching on right lines.
John Gill: A minister by taking heed to himself, and doctrine, saves himself from the pollutions of the world, from the errors and heresies of false teachers, from the blood of all men, and from all just blame in his ministry.
By faithfully preaching the Gospel to his hearers, [a minister] is instrumental in their eternal salvation.

Nothing can more animate and engage the ministers of the word to take heed to themselves and doctrine, and abide therein, than this, of being the happy instruments of converting sinners, and saving them from death.
John Wesley: Continue in them — In all the preceding advices.

bhtAttempts.bht: A good pastor must have two concerns: teaching earnestly and remaining pure. His teaching alone is not sufficient; his conduct must align with the doctrine he preaches. By holding fast to both his personal holiness and his teaching, he will save both himself and those who listen to him. It is crucial for a pastor to pay close attention to himself, ensuring that his life and teaching align with right principles. By doing so, he not only preserves himself from worldly corruption and false teachings but also becomes instrumental in the eternal salvation of others.

A good pastor must have two concerns: teaching earnestly and remaining pure. His teaching alone is not sufficient; his conduct must align with the doctrine he preaches. By holding fast to both his personal holiness and his teaching, he will save both himself and those who listen to him. It is crucial for a pastor to pay close attention to himself, ensuring that his life and teaching align with right principles. By doing so, he not only preserves himself from worldly corruption, but also becomes instrumental in the eternal salvation of others.

A good pastor needs to be diligent in teaching and maintaining personal purity. Their teaching is ineffective if it is not accompanied by a righteous life. By paying attention to both themselves and their teaching, pastors have the power to save themselves and their hearers. It is vital for pastors to adhere to right principles in their own lives and teaching in order to guide others towards salvation. This requires a steadfast commitment to both personal conduct and the proclamation of God's word.

A good pastor has two major concerns: teaching with passion and maintaining personal purity. It is not enough for a teacher to simply impart knowledge; they must exemplify a life that aligns with their instruction. By being dedicated to both their character and teaching, pastors can save not only themselves but also those who listen to them. Pastors must be diligent in upholding right principles in their own lives and teaching, as this will have a profound impact on the eternal salvation of their audience.

A good pastor has two primary responsibilities: teaching with sincerity and preserving personal integrity. Teaching without living out the principles being taught is futile. By maintaining a life in accordance with the teachings and being diligent in both personal conduct and preaching, a pastor not only safeguards their own salvation but also has the potential to bring about the salvation of those who listen. It is essential for pastors to remain faithful to the right principles in both their lives and teachings, impacting others' eternal destiny.
